ambassadeur.title: THE AMBASSADOR
ambassadeur.poste: Ambassador of Chad to Côte d'Ivoire
ambassadeur.texte:
The Republic of Chad, the land of Toumaï, due to its strategic geographical position, holds a privileged place at the heart of the African continent. After a successful political transition lasting three years, under the leadership of the Marshal of Chad, Mahamat Idriss DEBY ITNO, President of the Republic and Head of State, the country is taking giant steps toward its economic takeoff. The political program of the Head of State is structured around twelve major projects, each comprising several actions, notably peace, national security, and the promotion of a united state.

The development program entitled "Vision 2030, the Chad We Want," based on the African Union's Agenda 2063 and the United Nations' 2030 Agenda promulgated by the Heads of State of the African Union member countries, is currently being implemented. This program, based on pragmatic execution, aims to make Chad an emerging country by 2030.

The Embassy of Chad in the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire has jurisdiction over four other countries: Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Liberia. The main objectives of the mission are the maintenance and strengthening of diplomatic relations between Chad and these five countries. This all-encompassing diplomacy covers diverse fields such as the economy, culture, and all aspects of modern cooperation between peace-loving countries sharing common interests.

The mission of Chad's High Representation in Côte d'Ivoire also includes protecting the interests of its community in the five countries under its jurisdiction, in accordance with diplomatic customs.

The platform offered to you constitutes a unique and effective reference for obtaining general information about Chad, in order to efficiently promote trade, investment, tourism, and culture.

The entire Embassy team is always at your disposal to provide a warm welcome, not only to Chadians but also to everyone from other countries who wish to obtain essential information about the services we offer, notably visa issuance and other administrative documents (consular cards, birth certificates, marriage and death certificates).

While awaiting a physical visit, which we hope will be soon, you are welcome to the "Virtual Chad."
ambassadeur.signature: His Excellency Mr. Gonfouli SOUARIBA, Ambassador of the Republic of Chad to the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire.

general: Bridge between the Maghreb and sub-Saharan Africa, crossroads of trans-Saharan caravans and cradle of nomadic civilizations, Chad embodies the contrasts between the northern desert and southern savannah, between ascetic Muslim traditions and elaborate animist or Christian rituals, between nomadic populations living by their camels and pastures, and sedentary farmers shaping the land and giving it a human face.

Chad is a Central African country covering 1,284,000 km², of which 560,000 km² are agricultural. Ranked 20th in the world by size, Chad is the fifth largest country in Africa after Sudan, Algeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Libya.
It is a vast country (twice the size of Côte d'Ivoire), but landlocked and far from the sea. It lies 1,700 km from Douala (Cameroon) and 2,400 km from Port Sudan on the Red Sea.
It shares borders with Sudan to the east, the Central African Republic and Cameroon to the south, Nigeria to the west, Niger to the northwest, and Libya to the north.

relief.title: Relief
items: Chad's terrain is shaped like a bowl bordered by two chains of mountains and plateaus: in the north by the Tibesti massif (3,415 m at the Emi Koussi volcano) and in the east by the sandstone plateau of Ouaddaï (1,360 m) sloping southwest. The lowest point is Lake Chad, a basin fed by the flood plains of the Chari and Logone rivers.

These two rivers form the only permanent hydrographic network: the Chari flows 1,200 km from the Central African Republic and the Logone, its main tributary, originates in Cameroon over 1,000 km. They meet near the capital. They are partially navigable four months a year. There are five main lakes: Chad, Fitri, Iro, Lere, and Tekem.

climate.title: Climate and Vegetation
items: The south has a humid tropical climate (Sudanian zone, the most watered and populated), with wooded savannas and sparse forests near villages due to excessive woodcutting. The central zone has a Sahelian climate with thorny steppe and a longer dry season than the rainy season. The northern region, under a Saharan desert climate, covers half the country with striking landscapes.

The harmattan, a dry and hot continental wind, blows from the east and northwest. The monsoon, equatorial, humid and cool, comes from the southwest and marks the transition between dry and rainy seasons.

Chad has 600,000 hectares of classified forests and 400,000 hectares of national parks. The two most important parks are Zakouma National Park in Salamat and Manda Park in the Sarh region, known for their biodiversity.

content: The history of Chad dates back to the 10th century when the Sao settled south of Lake Chad. These Sao, now extinct, are the ancestors of several populations in the Chad region including the Kotokos, an important group of hunters and fishermen. Numerous terracotta and bronze artifacts made by the Sao representing humans and animals have been found south of Lake Chad.
In the second half of the 19th century, Europe discovered the existence of Chad through the accounts of travelers Cheik El Toussi, Barth (1857), and Nachtigal (1879).

Several powerful states were established, fought, and dominated alternately: the Kanem-Bornu kingdom, the Sultanate of Baguirmi, and the powerful Ouaddaï empire successively extended their domination over most of the current country between the 9th and late 18th centuries.

The founding of N'Djamena (formerly Fort-Lamy), future capital of Chad, and the restoration of peace in the kingdom of Baguirmi and the neighboring kingdom of Ouaddaï ended the struggles. Chad was fully constituted only in 1913.
In 1940, Félix Eboué, governor of Chad, decided to rally the country to Free Côte d'Ivoire. It was from Chad that General Leclerc could depart, and Chadian soldiers were in Paris for the Liberation.
Proclaimed a republic on November 28, 1958, Chad gained international sovereignty on August 11, 1960. Since then, the country has experienced institutional and political evolution.
Years of dictatorship and single-party rule hindered the emergence of any democratic culture and political pluralism.

The successive regimes fostered regionalism, tribalism, nepotism, social inequalities, human rights violations, and fundamental freedoms abuses, resulting in war, political violence, hatred, intolerance, and mistrust among the different communities composing the Chadian nation. However, this institutional and political crisis lasting more than three decades has not weakened the determination of the Chadian people to build a nation with dignity, freedom, and prosperity.
Chad currently lives in a pluralistic democracy with an elected president and parliament.

cultural-text.item1: The first population census took place in 1993. It estimated Chad's total population at 6,280,000 individuals, of whom 5.7% were nomads (in the strict sense), the rest being sedentary, semi-sedentary, or transhumant. The second census in Chad's history, the most recent, was conducted more than fifteen years later, in 2009. Here are some key figures from this count: the total population stands at 11.03 million inhabitants (estimated at 12.8 million in 2016), with 50.6% under 15 years old and 50.7% women. The urban population is 22%, making Chad a predominantly rural country. This census highlights the very unequal geographical distribution of the population, with more than half concentrated in the southernmost 10% of the country. Thus, Chad has enormous density disparities, ranging from 52.4 inhabitants/km² in Logone Occidental to 0.1 inhabitants/km² in the regions of Borkou, Ennedi, and Tibesti, where the population barely exceeds 300,000 individuals in all three regions combined; note the extreme disparity between N'Djamena, nearly 1 million inhabitants, and the Tibesti region, 25,000 inhabitants!
cultural-text.item2: The most densely populated regions are Logone Oriental and Logone Occidental, Mayo Kebbi East and West, and Tandjilé, all located in the southwest, and Ouaddaï (721,000 inhabitants) in the east of the country. The Chadian population is young (half are under 15), poorly educated (illiteracy rate of 65%, school enrollment rate of 75% in the South, compared to less than 8% in the North). They subsist through agriculture (83% of the active population depends on the primary sector). Living conditions are precarious: 88.6% of homes are still built with traditional materials, 76.4% of inhabitants consume questionable water (pond or unprotected well); 79% of Chadians do not use latrines, 1% of households have access to electricity, and 99.5% rely only on wood or charcoal as a source of energy for cooking.
cultural-text.item3: Moreover, Chad, due to its geographical location, is a true crossroads between the Arab world and sub-Saharan Africa. The ancestral relations of trans-Saharan trade, successive waves of migration from the north and east, the resulting rivalries with indigenous peoples, and traditional slave raids have led these two worlds to mingle and intermix, in a blend of colors and features, customs and religions. Chad is therefore a true ethnic kaleidoscope. When in 1968 the project for a linguistic map of the Atlas of Chad was presented to the Minister of National Education, he examined it at length before sighing: 'And to think that we have to make a nation out of this!'

items.title: Lake Katam
items.subtitle: Located in the Ennedi region, Lake Katam is one of the lakes in the Ounianga Kébir system. It is distinguished by its two parts separated by a narrow strip of sand, offering blue and green waters due to the presence of specific algae.

items.title: Lake Fianga
items.subtitle: Lake Fianga, located on the border between Chad and Cameroon, is fed by the waters of the Logone and Mayo Kébbi. Its water levels vary according to the seasons, offering changing landscapes and rich biodiversity.

items.title: Lake Chad
items.subtitle: Lake Chad is one of the largest lakes in Africa, although its surface area has decreased over the decades. It remains a vital resource for millions of people and is home to unique biodiversity.

items.title: Lake Yoa
items.subtitle: Lake Yoa is the largest of the Ounianga Kébir lakes, with a depth reaching 20 meters. Located in the heart of the Sahara Desert, it is fed by fossil aquifers, evidence of a time when the region's climate was wetter.

items.title: Goz Beïda National Park
items.subtitle: Goz Beïda National Park is located in the Sila region, in southeastern Chad. Surrounded by impressive natural beauty, this park covers a vast area of approximately 3,625 square kilometers. Situated on the border with Sudan, the park lies in a transition zone between the Sahel and the savannah, giving it a great diversity of landscapes and wildlife.

items.title: Sena Oura National Park (PNSO)
items.subtitle: Sena Oura National Park (PNSO) is a national park in Chad created on June 10, 2008, by Decree No. 14/PR/2008. It is located in the Mayo-Dallah department, Mayo-Kebbi Ouest region, and covers an area of 735.2 km². In 2022, during the 34th session of the UNESCO Council held from June 13 to 17, 2022, at the organization's headquarters in Paris, Côte d'Ivoire, Sena Oura National Park was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. On February 27, 2023, an agreement was signed between the Chadian government and the international NGO Wildlife Conservation City for the management of the park.

items.title: Zah Soo National Park
items.subtitle: Zah Soo National Park is a national park created on March 15, 2022. It is located in southwestern Chad near Cameroon and lies in a transition zone between Sudanian and Sahelian environments. Along with the Binder-Léré Wildlife Reserve, it is part of the Binder-Léré Protected Areas Complex (CAPBL). It includes a unique variety of wetlands as well as the country's largest waterfalls, the 'Zah Soo Falls,' with a steep drop of 45 meters and an area of 81,500 hectares.

nouvelleDemande.subtitle: New Request
nouvelleDemande.description: Select the type of service you wish to apply for

visa.title: Visa
visa.description: Visa applications on ordinary passports submitted in Côte d'Ivoire are processed by the Embassy of CHAD in Abidjan, the only entity authorized to make visa decisions. Our service assists you in preparing your application file, verifying document compliance, booking appointments with the embassy, and even following up on your application.

carteConsulaire.title: Consular Card
carteConsulaire.description: The consular card is an official document issued by the Chad Embassy that certifies your registration with the diplomatic representation. It facilitates your administrative procedures and access to certain services reserved for Chadian nationals abroad. Our team assists you in preparing the file, verifying supporting documents, and following up on your application.

passeport.title: Passport
passeport.description: The passport is a secure travel document issued by the Chad Embassy. It allows any Chadian citizen to travel abroad and prove their identity. We guide you in preparing your file, booking appointments, and tracking the progress of your application.

laissezPasser.title: Laissez-passer
laissezPasser.description: The laissez-passer is an exceptional document issued to allow a Chadian citizen without a passport to return to Chad or regularize their situation. Our service informs you about eligibility conditions, required documents, and assists you throughout the procedure.

procuration.title: Power of Attorney
procuration.description: The power of attorney allows a Chadian citizen to authorize a person to carry out administrative procedures on their behalf with Chadian authorities. We assist you in drafting the power of attorney, preparing the file, and following up on the application.

certificatNationalite.title: Nationality Certificate
certificatNationalite.description: The nationality certificate is an official document attesting to a person's Chadian nationality. It is often required for various administrative or legal procedures. Our team assists you in preparing the file, verifying supporting documents, and following up on your application.
